episode_title: 307 - The One With the Race Car Bed

content.description: Central Perk, the whole gang is there, Ross is telling a story about what happened at work and the rest of the gang are thinking to themselves, denoted by italics.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: So I told Carl, ‘Nobody, no matter how famous their parents are, nobody is allowed to climb on the dinosaur.’ But of course this went in one ear and out…

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I love how he cares so much about stuff. If I squint I can pretend he’s Alan Alda.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Oh good, another dinosaur story. When are those gonna become extinct?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: If I was a superhero who could fly and be invisible, that would be the best.

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: What does Rachel see in this guy? I love Rachel. I wish she was my wife.
(Joey is singing in his head.)

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Who’s singing?

content.description: [Scene: Monica and Rachel’s, the whole gang is there including Janice, they’re watching Happy Days.]

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Hey. When you guys were kids and you played Happy Days , who were you? I was always Richie.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: I was always Joanne.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Question. Was ah, ‘Egg the Gellers!’ the war cry of your neighbourhood?
(A commercial for the Mattress King, Janice’s ex-husband, comes on TV.)

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Ewww! Oh! It’s the Mattress King!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Booo!!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Don’t look honey. Change the channel! Change the channel!

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Wait! Wait! I wanna see this. After I divorce him, half of that kingdom is gonna be mine.

content.speaker: Matress King
content.text: ‘Despair fills the mattress showroom. My kingdom is suddenly without a queen. I’m so depressed I’m going to slash… my prices!! Check it out! Four ninety-nine for a pillow top queen set! I’m going medieval on prices!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: What a wank!

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Oh, I cannot believe he’s using our divorce to sell mattresses.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: I know! And four ninety-nine for a pillow top queen set, who cares about the divorce, those babies will sell themselves. (they all stare at her) And I’m appalled for you by the way.

content.speaker: Matress King
content.text: I’m close. I’m cheap. I’m the king.

content.description: Central Perk, Rachel is on the phone, everyone else is there except Joey.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: ‘Okay. (listens) Okay, daddy we’ll see you tomorrow night. (listens) Okay bye-bye.’ (hangs up)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: We?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Are ah, having dinner with my Dad tomorrow night, I hope that’s okay.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh shoot, tomorrow’s not so good, I’m supposed to um, fall off the Empire State building and land on a bicycle with no seat. Sorry.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Ross, my father doesn’t hate you.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Please, he refers to me as ‘wethead’.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: But honey he calls everybody by a nickname! Okay, look, I know, all right, just one dinner, please, just one night for me, please. I just want him to love you like I do. (Ross looks at her) All right, well not exactly like I do, but, but, if you do come to dinner, I’ll love you like I do in that black thing that you like.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: I’ll go.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Fine.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Thank you.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Hi Gunther.

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: Yeah, we’ll see!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey, you guys!

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Hey!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Guess what?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: What?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: I got a gig!

content.speaker: All
content.text: Yay!!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: See, that’s why I could never be an actor. Because I can’t say gig.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Yeah, I can’t say croissant. (realises) Oh my God!

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: What’s the part?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Well, it’s not a part, no. I’m teaching acting for soap operas down at the Learning Extension.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Come on! That’s great.

content.speaker: All
content.text: Wow!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Yeah, yeah. It’s like my chance to give something back to the acting community.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Y’know your probably not allowed to sleep with any of your students.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: I know!

content.description: Mattress King, Monica and Phoebe are shopping for a new mattress.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Ugh! I don’t know Monica. It feels funny just being here. I mean if you buy a bed from Janice’s ex-husband, that’s like betraying Chandler.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Not at these prices.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: (to kid) Hi. Y’know in England this car would be on the other side of the store. (the kid just stares at her, and she makes the ‘that went right over your head’ motion) Woo!
content.parenthetical: sees a little kid playing with a race car bed

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Oh! Ohhhhh! Oh! Phoebe, come here. Aw, this is my new bed. You gotta feel this bad boy.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Eh, Monica it, it feels so weird, y’know, Chandler’s your friend… (hops onto the bed) Oh! Oh my God! Aw, all right take this bed, you can make other friends.

content.description: Classroom. Joey is writing his name on the board, but turns around before he’s done which causes him to write his name with a downward curve, and he then underlines it, and draws the line right through his name.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Good evening. I’m Mr. Tribbiani. And I will be teaching acting for soap operas. Now um, on my first day as (proudly) Dr. Drake Remoray on Days of Our Lives , (looks for a reaction from his students, and gets none.) I learned that one of the most important things in soap opera acting is reacting, this does not mean acting again, it means, you don’t have a line, but someone else just did. And it goes like this. (looks all intense for a moment and then gasps, the students cheer him) Thanks, thanks, a lot. Oh, by the way, before I forget to work in soap operas some of you will have to become much more attractive. All right, moving right along.

content.description: Monica and Rachel’s, Joey is entering, Phoebe is already there waiting for the delievery guy.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hi!

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Hey! Ooh! How was teaching last night?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Oh it was great. Yeah, you get to say stuff like, ’Hey, the bell doesn’t dismiss you, I dismiss you.’

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Ooooh, nice.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Oh, and guess what, I got an audition for All My Children .

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh, yay!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Yeah, it’s this great part, this boxer named Nick. And I’m so, so right for it, y’know, he’s just like me. Except he’s a boxer, and has an evil twin.
(There is a knock on the door.)

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh. (goes and answers the door and there is this huge black delievery guy.)

content.speaker: Guy
content.text: Dom da-da dom! Here ye! Here ye! Delivery from the Mattress King. (to Phoebe) You Miss Geller?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Okay.

content.speaker: Guy
content.text: Sign here. (hands her a clipboard)

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh, do I have a middle name. All right Monica Velula Geller. It’s that bedroom there. (points to Monica’s room)

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey, Monica bought a bed from the Mattress King?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Yeah, so please, please, please, don’t say anything to Chandler.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: You want me to lie to Chandler?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Is that a problem?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: No.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh, hey, hey Nick the boxer let’s see what you got. All right ya, put ‘em up. Come on. (they start shadow boxing)

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey, you’re ah, pretty good at this.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Yeah, well I had to learn, I was staying at the Y and some off the young men weren’t acting Christian enough.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Ahh!
(Joey throws a punch and just lightly taps her on the shoulder, Phoebe counters with a jab to the nose.)

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey now!
(Phoebe throws another jab, and lands it on Joey’s nose, causing it to bleed.)

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey!!! Oww!! And I’m bleeding.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh! Oh! Oh!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Okay, great.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Wow! And I’m a vegetarian! All right, all right, well I’m sorry, we’ll put some ice on it.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Okay.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: ‘Kay, put your head back.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: All right. I can’t see.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: All right, I have ya. Oh God.

content.speaker: Guy
content.text: Which bedroom do ya want it in Miss Geller?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh, it’s the compulsively neat one by the window, okay.

content.speaker: Guy
content.text: Gotcha. (he and his helper walk in carrying the racecar bed.)

content.description: Restaurant, Rachel and Ross and Dr. Green are having dinner.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Hi Daddy!

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: This where they put it? What, there no table available in the kitchen! Hello, baby.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: You remember Ross.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Um-hmm.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Nice to see you again Dr. Green.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: So! (they both try to sit next to Rachel but Dr. Green is successful.) (to Ross) How’s the library?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Ugh, museum.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: What happened to the library?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: There never was a library. I mean there are libraries, its just that I ah, I never worked at one.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: You know what’s really good here, the lobster. What do you say shall I just order three.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Yeah, if you’re really hungry. (Dr. Green stares at him) It was a joke, I made a joke.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yeah, actually Daddy Ross is allergic to lobster.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: What kind of person is allergic to lobster? I guess the kind of person that works at a library.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: It’s not a library…

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: I know!! It’s a museum! What, you’re the only one around here who can make a joke! At least mine was funny. Ah, waiter, we will have two lobsters and a menu. (nods at Ross, and mouths I don’t know to the waiter.)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: So, Dr. Green, how’s the old boat.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: They found rust. You know what rust does to a boat?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: It gives it a nice antiquey look.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Rust, is boat cancer, Ross.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Wow. I’m sorry, when I was a kid I lost a bike to that. (Rachel giggles at that)

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Excuse me for a moment, will you please, I want to say good night to the Levines, before we go.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Okay.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Okay! (picks up a knife and pretends to stab his heart.)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Aw honey stop! It’s not that bad.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Yeah. (sees the bill) Op! Uh-oh! I think your Dad must’ve added wrong. He only tipped like four percent.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yeah. That’s Daddy.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: That’s Daddy?! But doesn’t it bother you? You’re a waitress.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yes, it bothers me Ross, but y’know if he was a regular at the coffee house, I’d be serving him sneezers.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: So?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: So. Ross, I’ve bugged him about this a million times, he’s not gonna change.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: You really serve people sneezers?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Well um, I don’t.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: You kids ready?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Thanks again, Dr. Green.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: All right.
(Ross takes a twenty and slips it underneath the bill when Dr. Green isn’t looking.)

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Oh, wait, wait, wait, wait, I think I forgot my receipt.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh, ah, you don’t need that.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Why not?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: The carbon, it’s messy, I mean it gets on your fingers and causes, the, the ah, night blindness.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: What is this? Who put a twenty down here? Huh?
content.parenthetical: gets his receipt and notices the twenty

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh, yeah, that would be me, um, I have, I have a problem I-I tip way too much, way, way, too much, it’s a sickness really.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yeah it is, it is. (to Ross) We really, really have to do something about that.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: I know.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Excuse me, you think I’m cheap?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Oh Daddy, no he didn’t mean anything by that, he really didn’t.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Nothing I do means anything, really.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: This is nice. I pay two hundred dollars for dinner, you put down twenty, and you come out looking like Mr. Big Shot. You really want to be Mr. Big Shot? Here, I’ll tell you what, you pay the whole bill, Mr. Big Shot, all right. (rips up the bill, and throws it at Ross, then leaves)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Well Mr. Big Shot is better than ‘wethead’.

content.description: Classroom, Joey is lecturing on facial expressions.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Okay, some tricks of the trade. Now, I’ve never been able to cry as an actor, so if I’m in a scene where I have to cry, I cut a hole in my pocket, take a pair of tweezers, and just start pulling. Or ah, or, let’s say I wanna convey that I’ve just done something evil. That would be the basic ‘I have a fishhook in my eyebrow and I like it’ (Does it by raising one eyebrow, and showing off the pretend fishhook.) Okay, let’s say I’ve just gotten bad news, well all I do there is try and divide 232 by 13. (looks all confused) And that’s how it’s done. Great soap opera acting tonight everybody, class dismissed.

content.speaker: Student
content.text: Hey, Mr. Trib.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey-hey.

content.speaker: Student
content.text: Guess what, I got an audition!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Awww, one of my students got an audition. I’m so proud.

content.speaker: Student
content.text: I was wondering if you would consider coaching me for it?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: You bet! What’s the part?

content.speaker: Student
content.text: Oh it’s great, it’s a role on All My Children , Nick the boxer.
(Joey does the ‘232 divided by 13 bad news’ look.)

content.description: Hallway, Ross and Rachel are returning from dinner.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: You had to do it, didn’t you? You couldn’t just leave it alone.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Four percent. Okay. I tip more than that when there’s a bug in my food.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Ross, tonight was about the two of you getting along. (Ross groans and rubs his neck) Oh, would you just see my chiropractor, already.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Yeah, I’m gonna go to a doctor who went to school in a mini-mall.
(they go into Monica and Rachel’s, and see Phoebe hopping around.)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Hey Pheebs, what are you doing?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I’m, I’m freaking out! Monica kinda trusted me with something and she shouldn’t have! All right, I haven’t lived here in a while, so I have to ask you something. Does Monica still turn on the lights in her bedroom?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Um. yeah.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I am soo dead. (goes to Monica’s room)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: All right, look, here’s the bottom line Ross, this is fixable, if we act fast, okay. So, I’ll invite him to brunch tomorrow and you can make nice.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Look, honey, I have tried to make nice, it doesn’t work.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Okay, look, Ross, I realise that my Father is difficult, but that’s why you have got to be the bigger man here.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Look sweetie, I could be the bigger man, I could be the biggest man, I could be a big, huge, giant man, and it still wouldn’t make any difference, except that I could pick your Father up and say ‘Like me! Like me tiny doctor!’

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Okay, well can’t you just try it one more time Ross? For me? For me?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Rachel one brunch is not gonna solve anything. You gotta face it, okay we’re never gonna get along.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Okay, well you are just gonna have too, okay. Because I already got a Mother and a Father who cannot stay in the same room together, okay, I don’t wanna have to have a separate room for you too!! (starts to cry)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Okay, okay, okay. (hugs her) I’ll get the bagels.

content.description: Monica’s bedroom, Phoebe is trying to hide the bed from Monica.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: What’s this?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Isn’t it cool! Varoom! Varoom!

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: This is not the bed I ordered!

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I know, you must’ve won like a contest or something!
(Phoebe starts to make a sound like a car accelerating)

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Phoebe!
(Phoebe makes a sound like a car screeching to a halt.)

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Why is this car in my bedroom?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I’m sorry, okay, I-I wasn’t looking, and the store says that they won’t take it back because you signed for it…

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: When did I sign for it?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: When I was you! Y’know what, it’s all Joey’s fault, ‘cause he left his nose open!

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Did you make brownies today?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Knock, knock.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Quick, take off your dress, he won’t notice the bed.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Hey, I’m going for sushi does anybody want.. (enters and sees the bed) Whoa-whoa, somebody missed the off ramp.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: It’s Monica’s bed. What?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Okay. (to Monica) It’s a racecar.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: So. This has always been Monica’s bed, what you’re just noticing now, how self-involved are you?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Okay, well it this bed isn’t new, how come there is plastic on the mattress?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Sometimes I have bad dreams. (starts to break down, and Phoebe offers her, her hand to comfort her.)

content.description: Classroom, Joey is coaching his student.

content.speaker: Student
content.text: Look, I just saw my best friends brains smeared across the canvas, that’s not gonna be me, not me.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Wow! That was good. That was…(points to his pocket) Tweezers?

content.speaker: Student
content.text: No.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Whoa. That was really good.

content.speaker: Student
content.text: Thanks, any suggestions?
(Joey gets the evil look on his face.)

content.description: Central Perk, Chandler, Monica, and Phoebe are there, yelling at Joey.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: You told him to play the boxer gay!!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Well, I-I might’ve said supergay.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: You totally screwed him over.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Joey, you’re this guy’s teacher. I mean how could you do this?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Because, Monica, the guy’s so good, and I really, really want this part.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Well, if you really, really want it, then it’s okay.

content.description: Monica and Rachel’s, Rachel is greeting her Father for their brunch.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Hi Daddy.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Baby. Ross.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Dr. Green. How are you? (offers his hand, and Dr. Green puts his scarf on it.)

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Thanks for dinner last night.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Thank you for teaching me a valuable lesson.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Nice hair. What’d ya do? Swim here?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Okay, that’s it, I can’t take it anymore.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: What? What? He’s interested in you. He-he likes your hair, he just wants to know how you got here.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh, please. Sweetie it’s hopeless, okay, I’m just gonna go. (starts to leave rubbing his neck)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: What?!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Look, look I’m sorry. It’s just that…

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Ross? What’s with the neck?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: He’s got this thing. And I keep telling him to go to my chiropractor…

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: You’re still going to that chiropractor, that man couldn’t get into medical school in Extapa!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Thank you! That’s what I keep saying.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Excuse me, Dr. Bobby happens to be an excellent doctor.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Uh.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Wait a minute, his name is Dr. Bobby?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Well that’s his last name.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: And his first name.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: He’s Bobby Bobby?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: It’s Robert Bobby.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Oh.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: And um, excuse me, he helps me.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh-ho please. Ask her how?

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: What do you need help for?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: With my alignment. I’ve got one leg shorter than the other.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Oh God!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Argue with that.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: What? It’s true, my right leg is two inches shorter.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Come on! You’re just titling! (to Ross) Her legs are fine!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: I know that!

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: So, why do you let her go to a chiropractor for?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I’m sorry, let her?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: What can I do, she doesn’t listen to me about renter’s insurance either.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Wait a minute, you don’t have renter’s insurance?!

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: No.

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: Well what if somebody steals something? How are you gonna run after him with one leg shorter than the other?!
(Both he and Ross start laughing)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Hey, would you ah, would you like some juice?

content.speaker: Dr. Green
content.text: I’d love some juice. Thanks.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Okay. (to Rachel) Wow! This is going so well. Did you see us? Did you see?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yeah honey, I’m standing right there! Why didn’t you just tell him about the mole I haven’t got checked yet.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Excellent!

content.description: Classroom, Joey is talking to his students.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: There will come a time in each of your careers when you’ll have a chance to screw over another soap opera actor. I had such an opportunity in the recent, present. And I’m ashamed to say that I took it, I advised a fellow actor to play a role, homosexually. Yeah, we both auditioned for the part, and uh, as it turned out, they ah, they liked the stupid gay thing and cast him. And now, he’s got a two year contract opposite Susan Luchhi, the first lady of daytime television, and me, me I’m stuck here teaching a bunch of people, most of whom are too ugly to even be on TV. I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I’m sorry. (he gets a huge round of applause from his students.) Thank you.

content.description: Mattress King, Monica is trying to return her bed.

content.speaker: Jester
content.text: Uh, may I help you?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Yeah, I talked to you on the phone, I’m the lady that got stuck with the racecar bed.

content.speaker: Jester
content.text: Look, it’s like I told you, there’s nothing I can do. You signed for it, Monica Velula Geller.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: All right, Jester man, look we wanna see the king.

content.speaker: Jester
content.text: Nobody sees the king!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Oh-ho-kay, I’m talking to the king. (starts to go to a back room)

content.speaker: Jester
content.text: Hey! You can’t go back there!
(Joey goes to the door, but stops and looks through the window at Janice and the Mattress King, her ex-husband, kissing.)

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Oh my God.
(Joey fakes a scream.)

content.description: Monica’s bedroom, Chandler is playing with the bed.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Varrrrrroom! Hey! Watch it lady! Varrrrrrrrrrom! (makes a screeching sound as he pretends to stomp on the brakes.) Hey-hey good lookin’! (honks the bed’s little horn on the steering wheel.) Varrrrrrrrroom. (notices Rachel and stops) All right, I’ll leave. My bed’s so boring.
